segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes the Advanced Security Audit policy setting, Audit Logoff, which determines whether the operating system generates audit events when logon sessions are terminated.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes the Advanced Security Audit policy setting, Audit Logoff, which determines whether the operating system generates audit events when logon sessions are terminated.

segment.source: Audit Logoff determines whether the operating system generates audit events when logon sessions are terminated.
segment.target: Audit Logoff determines whether the operating system generates audit events when logon sessions are terminated.

segment.source: These events occur on the computer that was accessed.
segment.target: These events occur on the computer that was accessed.

segment.source: In the case of an interactive logon, these events are generated on the computer that was logged on to.
segment.target: In the case of an interactive logon, these events are generated on the computer that was logged on to.

segment.source: There is no failure event in this subcategory because failed logoffs (such as when a system abruptly shuts down) do not generate an audit record.
segment.target: There is no failure event in this subcategory because failed logoffs (such as when a system abruptly shuts down) do not generate an audit record.

segment.source: Logon events are essential to understanding user activity and detecting potential attacks.
segment.target: Logon events are essential to understanding user activity and detecting potential attacks.

segment.source: Logoff events are not 100 percent reliable.
segment.target: Logoff events are not 100 percent reliable.

segment.source: For example, the computer can be turned off without a proper logoff and shutdown; in this case, a logoff event is not generated.
segment.target: For example, the computer can be turned off without a proper logoff and shutdown; in this case, a logoff event is not generated.

segment.source: This subcategory allows you to audit events generated by the closing of a logon session.
segment.target: This subcategory allows you to audit events generated by the closing of a logon session.

segment.source: These events occur on the computer that was accessed.
segment.target: These events occur on the computer that was accessed.

segment.source: For an interactive logoff the security audit event is generated on the computer that the user account logged on to.
segment.target: For an interactive logoff the security audit event is generated on the computer that the user account logged on to.

segment.source: This subcategory typically generates huge amount of “4634(S): An account was logged off.”
segment.target: This subcategory typically generates huge amount of “4634(S): An account was logged off.”

segment.source: events which, typically has little security relevance.
segment.target: events which, typically has little security relevance.

segment.source: It is more important to audit Logon events using Audit Logon subcategory, rather than Logoff events.
segment.target: It is more important to audit Logon events using Audit Logon subcategory, rather than Logoff events.

segment.source: Enable Success audit if you want to track, for example, for how long session was active (in correlation with Audit Logon events) and when user actually logged off.
segment.target: Enable Success audit if you want to track, for example, for how long session was active (in correlation with Audit Logon events) and when user actually logged off.

segment.source: This subcategory doesn’t have Failure events, so there is no recommendation to enable Failure auditing for this subcategory.
segment.target: This subcategory doesn’t have Failure events, so there is no recommendation to enable Failure auditing for this subcategory.

segment.source: This subcategory typically generates huge amount of “4634(S): An account was logged off.”
segment.target: This subcategory typically generates huge amount of “4634(S): An account was logged off.”

segment.source: events which, typically has little security relevance.
segment.target: events which, typically has little security relevance.

segment.source: It is more important to audit Logon events using Audit Logon subcategory, rather than Logoff events.
segment.target: It is more important to audit Logon events using Audit Logon subcategory, rather than Logoff events.

segment.source: Enable Success audit if you want to track, for example, for how long session was active (in correlation with Audit Logon events) and when user actually logged off.
segment.target: Enable Success audit if you want to track, for example, for how long session was active (in correlation with Audit Logon events) and when user actually logged off.

segment.source: This subcategory doesn’t have Failure events, so there is no recommendation to enable Failure auditing for this subcategory.
segment.target: This subcategory doesn’t have Failure events, so there is no recommendation to enable Failure auditing for this subcategory.

segment.source: This subcategory typically generates huge amount of “4634(S): An account was logged off.”
segment.target: This subcategory typically generates huge amount of “4634(S): An account was logged off.”

segment.source: events which, typically has little security relevance.
segment.target: events which, typically has little security relevance.

segment.source: It is more important to audit Logon events using Audit Logon subcategory, rather than Logoff events.
segment.target: It is more important to audit Logon events using Audit Logon subcategory, rather than Logoff events.

segment.source: Enable Success audit if you want to track, for example, for how long session was active (in correlation with Audit Logon events) and when user actually logged off.
segment.target: Enable Success audit if you want to track, for example, for how long session was active (in correlation with Audit Logon events) and when user actually logged off.

segment.source: This subcategory doesn’t have Failure events, so there is no recommendation to enable Failure auditing for this subcategory.
segment.target: This subcategory doesn’t have Failure events, so there is no recommendation to enable Failure auditing for this subcategory.
